Thanks for taking care of this. Can you merge this once https://github.com/apache/incubator-systemml/pull/231 is in.
Awesome, LGMT.
Yeah definitely.
@nakul02 Should we also enable -gpu via MLContext ?
I've addressed the "lower-case handling" on the Java side. Let me know if that is ok.
@MechCoder This looks good -- can you fix the Java formatting, and then I can merge this in.
done and rebased
Merged. Thanks, @MechCoder!
Ping @asurve Can you close this PR?
Thank you for the left and right indexing!!
LGTM ðŸ‘
Pending [Jenkins](https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-OnDemand/203/) Job
@dusenberrymw Would you mind trying out this update and see if it has a better feel to Spark developers?
cc @bertholdreinwald

The `toDF` looks good.  I might recommend using `toRDDStringIJV` and related variants to make it clear that those methods are for getting a string representation of a row of numbers.  This way, we can add a `toRDDIJV` function that returns a proper tuple of numbers.   The string formats are old anyways, and we should probably deprecate them at some point.

Also, can you double check that the Python MLContext `toDF` function is updated to use this new Java `toDF` function?  Should be a quick change confirmed with tests.
LGTM as a temporary fix, but we should drop this from the official 1.0 docs.  At that point, we should create versioned documentation.
Definitely agree. Part of the process of our web upgrade and next release should be to ensure we have versioned documentation online so that we can remove this.
Thanks for the feedback @dusenberrymw. I will add the 'String' to the RDD methods to avoid confusion in the future.
I will merge this today if there are no objections.
Requested changes made. I will merge.

@mboehm7 
Is the conditional "if (_metaData instanceof NumItemsByEachReducerMetaData)" check necessary for frames or can this be removed?
All tests passed: https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/646/console
no it's not required as frames are not supported in the MR backend yet.

If an MLContext hasn't been created and it is required, here is an example of the new behavior:

```
scala> val LinRegCg = LinRegCgDML.in("X", X).in("y", y).out("beta_out")
No MLContext object is currently active. Have you created one? Hint: in Scala, 'val ml = new MLContext(sc)'
```

Stacktrace is suppressed in this situation since it is irrelevant for the user.
@mboehm7 Thank you
cc @dusenberrymw @bertholdreinwald
ping @bertholdreinwald

This LGTM.  We might also want to think about adding an optional `set_index(...)` function, like Pandas has [1].

[1]: http://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/generated/pandas.DataFrame.set_index.html
Oh also, can you check that the Python test still run, and that the Python examples are still correct?
LGTM.
LGTM.
Verified that test_mlcontext.py still works. I've never been able to run test_mllearn.py on my machine.
Thank you @dusenberrymw. I will merge.

I would recommend to close this PR - for right indexing (as modified here) the input cannot be a scalar. If indexing on a scalar comes indeed down to the runtime, we need to change the validation in DMLTranslator instead. Furthermore, any related change should be done consistently for left and right indexing (not just right indexing).

@mboehm7 -
When this script is run against master :

``` r
B = "hello"
C = B[1,1]
print(C)
```

The following error is printed:
Caused by: org.apache.sysml.runtime.DMLRuntimeException: Variable 'hello' does not exist in the symbol table.

The error being printed out is :  **Variable 'hello' does not exist in the symbol table.** 
Whereas the core issue is of trying to index a scalar.

Here is another more interesting example:

``` r
A = matrix(1, rows=1, cols=10)
B = sum(A %*% t(A))
C = B[1,1]
print(C)
```

And the error message:

```
16/09/12 11:23:30 ERROR api.DMLScript: Failed to execute DML script.
org.apache.sysml.runtime.DMLRuntimeException: org.apache.sysml.runtime.DMLRuntimeException: ERROR: Runtime error in program block generated from statement block between lines 1 and 4 -- Error evaluating instruction: CPÂ°rangeReIndexÂ°_Var3Â·SCALARÂ·DOUBLEÂ·falseÂ°1Â·SCALARÂ·INTÂ·trueÂ°1Â·SCALARÂ·INTÂ·trueÂ°1Â·SCALARÂ·INTÂ·trueÂ°1Â·SCALARÂ·INTÂ·trueÂ°_Var4Â·SCALARÂ·DOUBLE

        at org.apache.sysml.runtime.controlprogram.context.ExecutionContext.getFrameInput(ExecutionContext.java:351)
```

The error message is : **Variable '_Var3' is not a frame.**

In both cases, `DMLTranslator` is not doing the appropriate error checking.
I think `DMLTranslator` should have that check, but having a redundant check in the runtime is not a bad idea. 
While the current implementation detects the error, a user of DML/PyDML would not be able to comprehend the error messages. 
I faced this error when helping @asurve build his SystemML demo for his meetup.

Actually, I'd be interested in changing `toNumPyArray()` to `toNumPy()`.  Then we could have `toDF()`, `toNumPy()`, `toPandas()`, `toList()`, etc.

Thoughts?

The following mvn test command now generates no "Only one SparkContext may be running in this JVM" exceptions for me:

```
mvn surefire:test -Dtest=FrameTest,MLContextTest,MLContextFrameTest,GNMFTest
```

@mboehm7 Could you let me know if this fixes the tests running in a single JVM for you?
cc @nakul02

I am not much of a python programmer, but here are my 2 cents:
`toDF()` might be ok
`toNumPy` and `toPandas()` make sense if **NumPy** and **Pandas** offer exactly on data type/data structure.
LGTM. Thank you @nakul02.
All tests passed here: https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-OnDemand/204/console

Yeah in this case we're following Spark conventions by using `toDF()` & `toPandas()`, which return a Spark DataFrame and a Pandas DataFrame respectively in Spark right now.  `toNumPy()` would return a NumPy array specifically, and would follow along with the same conventions.

If there are no objections, I will merge this tomorrow.  Also, @nakul02 this may require a slight function change in the demo you've been working on.
Good call, @nakul02.  What are the executable names now?  Before, it would have installed `spark-shell`, `pyspark`, etc.  Does it have the version appended now?
All tests pass here: https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-OnDemand/205/console
cc @dusenberrymw

I like the idea of having `toDF()` and `toPandas()` as they are consistent with PySpark's API: https://spark.apache.org/docs/1.3.0/api/python/pyspark.sql.html

I would refer to @dusenberrymw and @MechCoder regarding `toNumPy()` or `toNumPyArray` or `toNumpyMatrix` or `as_matrix`: http://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/generated/pandas.DataFrame.as_matrix.html
Okay great.  I'm going to go with `toNumPy()` for now as it is short and clean, and prevents any confusion between SystemML "matrices" and NumPy "matrices".

I think they're still called `spark-shell`, `pyspark`.
The [homebrew/versions tap](https://github.com/Homebrew/homebrew-versions/blob/master/apache-spark16.rb) recipe just gets Spark 1.6.2 instead of the [default homebrew-core](https://github.com/Homebrew/homebrew-core/blob/master/Formula/apache-spark.rb) recipe which gets 2.0.
Thanks Nakul for looking into this. We should also consider adding Window's instruction in subsequent PR :)
Thanks @asurve, here is the [JIRA](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SYSTEMML-920)
@niketanpansare - Could you please merge this in?
@MadisonJMyers Can you make this change in your blog post(s)?
@deroneriksson or @dusenberrymw - Could you please merge this in, @niketanpansare has a permission issue.
@dusenberrymw yes! will do.

All unit tests passed with version 4.5:
https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-OnDemand/206/

Also ran Linear Regression example (genLinearRegression, sample, splitXY, LinearRegDS, GLM-predict) against spark-submit 1.6.1.
Note spark 2.0 bundles antlr4-runtime-4.5.3.jar.

Switched back to 4.5 used on test branch for on demand build 206 due to below error when using 4.5.3:

[INFO] --- antlr4-maven-plugin:4.5.3:antlr4 (antlr) @ systemml ---
[INFO] ANTLR 4: Processing source directory /a/workspace/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/src/main/java
[INFO] Processing grammar: org/apache/sysml/parser/dml/Dml.g4
[INFO] Processing grammar: org/apache/sysml/parser/pydml/Pydml.g4
[ERROR] error(159): org/apache/sysml/parser/pydml/Pydml.g4:407:0: cannot declare a rule with reserved name SKIP
[ERROR] /a/workspace/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/org/apache/sysml/parser/pydml/Pydml.g4 [407:0]: cannot declare a rule with reserved name SKIP

@dusenberrymw On the Java side, looks like the bigint gets converted to a long, so I added a check for DataTypes.LongType. Can be verified with:

```
import org.apache.spark.mllib.linalg._
val row1 = (1L, Vectors.dense(1.0,2.0,3.0))
val row2 = (2L, Vectors.dense(4.0,5.0,6.0))
val rdd = sc.parallelize(Array(row1, row2))
val df = rdd.toDF("__INDEX", "C1")
df.show

import org.apache.sysml.api.mlcontext._
val ml = new MLContext(sc)
val scr = ScriptFactory.dml("print(toString(M))").in("M", df)
ml.execute(scr)
```

I also updated the tests to use DataTypes.IntegerType.

The following is now confirmed to work on PySpark:

``` python
from systemml import MLContext, dml
from pyspark.mllib.linalg import Vectors

X = sc.parallelize([(1, Vectors.dense([3.4,4.3,5.3])), (2, Vectors.dense([5.2,6.5,7.0]))]).toDF(["__INDEX", "sample"])

ml = MLContext(sc)
script = """
s = sum(X)
"""
script = dml(script).input(X=X).output("s")
s = ml.execute(script).get("s")
```
Thank you for including the PySpark example. Very helpful if needed later.
Unit tests again passed in [PR build 659](https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/659/).

Hi @gweidner. Would you mind seeing if the main SystemML artifacts will work after upgrading the ANTLR version? I have some examples at http://apache.github.io/incubator-systemml/release-process.html (search for the "# build distribution artifacts"). ANTLR has a couple compile-scope dependencies (see pom's antlr4-runtime entry) which can sometimes make things tricky.
Great catch @deroneriksson!  Let me test those as well.  Also big thank you for showing license impact so more for me to do here.

Clarification on differences between 4.5.x releases available here:
https://github.com/antlr/antlr4/releases

From 4.5 summary of changes at https://github.com/antlr/antlr4/releases:
"Be aware that we no longer deploy a maven antlr4-annotations artifact and in fact we no longer use Java annotations in the Java runtime and so that code is disappeared."

So assembly/license files to be updated accordingly in additional commit under this PR.
Can an Admin verify this patch?
Yes, just run the example and it should run without errors

Thanks, Romeo. LGTM. But please change your comment in line 2290 from "in case it does not compile ..." to something like: "For Spark version <= 1.6.0 use createDataFrame(), and for Spark version >= 1.6.1 use .toDF()"
ok, done, thanks for the suggestion, please let me know in case you want me to change something else..
@gweidner Thank you for tracking down the dependency change. Removal of a compile-scope dependency is always a very welcome change. :-)

@romeokienzler Welcome to SystemML! Would you mind committing these changes on the master branch rather than the gh-pages branch? The master copy of the documentation lives on the master branch, and we push the docs subtree to gh-pages for publishing on GitHub. Since gh-pages has a different base directory from the master branch, this makes merging difficult.

Thanks Deron for handling!

LGTM
@gweidner Thank you for reviewing. I appreciate it.
Since no consensus could be reached and the MLContext API allows data input without what I would consider burdensome mandatory metadata requirements, I'll close this PR.
Can an Admin verify this patch?
Yes, just run the code on Spark 1.6.X and it breaks, use my two lines and it works on 1.6.X
Ok, [done](https://github.com/apache/incubator-systemml/pull/246)

Hi @romeokienzler. In PR245 you also included the import and creation of the sqlContext. Should this be included or should this PR be merged as is?

Thank you for committing to the master branch.
add to whitelist
add to whitelist
Actually, looking at the usage, the current commit looks great since the sqlContext is used in the commented code. LGTM. Thank you @romeokienzler. I will merge.
This update is now available publicly here: http://apache.github.io/incubator-systemml/spark-mlcontext-programming-guide.html
@deroneriksson I've double checked, the SQL-Context is needed indeed, so I've created a new [pull request](https://github.com/apache/incubator-systemml/pull/248)

@deroneriksson [Here](https://apache.github.io/incubator-systemml/spark-mlcontext-programming-guide#helper-methods-1) the sqlContext is needed again, that's the reason I've created it - now I've commited a better solution by importing import sqlContext.implicits._ I don't know (since this tutorial is written for Zeppelin and I'm using jupyther on IBM Data Science Workbench if sqlContext and the import for sqlContext.implicits._ is done by Zeppelin itself, do you know that? But anyways, this solution works for [this](https://apache.github.io/incubator-systemml/spark-mlcontext-programming-guide#generate-linear-regression-test-data) but [this](https://apache.github.io/incubator-systemml/spark-mlcontext-programming-guide#helper-methods-1) definitely doesn't work in Jupyter. Once [this](https://github.com/apache/incubator-systemml/pull/248) pull request is merged I can work on the fix for [this](https://apache.github.io/incubator-systemml/spark-mlcontext-programming-guide#helper-methods-1)  section as well
Its not working in some cases, trying to debug it further.

thanks @asurve - could you also comment on how you tested it (the most important question to answer is how to do this configuration management on an already created spark context that is passed from outside into mlcontext). Also, I would recommend to extend this PR to all explicitly handled spark configurations (i.e., include spark.scheduler.mode).
Created JIRAs SYSTEMML-931 to SYSTEMML-939 of issues that are not covered by this PR.

LGTM ðŸ‘ 

There are is a test failing marked by @niketanpansare in JIRA [931](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SYSTEMML-931) 

Other JIRAs  SYSTEMML-[932](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SYSTEMML-932) to [939](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SYSTEMML-939) contain other tasks related to this commit.

We can work on those JIRAs after this gets committed.

@deroneriksson @lresende As mentioned earlier, I believe the build related concerns are addressed. Like Java, .cu files (corresponding to .java files) are checked into git and .ptx files (corresponding to .class files) are compiled into the jar using mvn:

``` bash
mvn clean prepare-package -DenableGPU=true
mvn package -Pdistribution
```

The first command invokes `nvcc -ptx SystemML.cu -o SystemML.ptx` and the next command simply puts SystemML.ptx into the jar as resource :)

It seems setting maxResultSize after SparkContext started does not get reflected. It needs to be set before starting SparkContext. User needs to set it through configuration like
  On command line by adding following for unlimited size (which SystemML prefers)
     --conf spark.driver.maxResultSize=0

well, in that case, I would recommend to throw a warning if a spark context with maxResultSize < local_memory_budget is passed in. 

An alternative would be to automatically lower the local memory budget to the max result size but this has many negative implications for local operations and broadcasts and hence is no real solution.

In ANTLR 4.5.1, an issue was reported when rule used reserved name (e.g., SKIP).
    https://github.com/antlr/antlr4/issues/967
This was fixed in ANTLR 4.5.2:
    https://github.com/antlr/antlr4/issues/996
    https://github.com/antlr/antlr4/issues/1015
Pushed PyDML.g4 and pom.xml so rule name no longer conflicts with reserved name.
